data.name: Falling Factorials
data.description:
The **falling factorial** of a number `$x$` of order `$n$`, denoted by `$x^{\underbar{\textit{n}}}$`, is defined by
```math
\qquad x^{\underbar{\textit{n}}} = \underbrace{x(x - 1)(x - 2) \dotsb (x - n + 1)}_{\textrm{\# of factors is } n}
```
Given a number `x` and a nonnegative integer `n`, compute `$x^{\underbar{\textit{n}}}$`. Answers within `0.001` of the correct answer will be accepted.

## Example 1
If `$x = 5$` and `$n = 3$`, then
```math
\qquad\begin{aligned} 5^{\underbar 3} &= 5 \cdot (5 - 1) \cdot (5 - 2) \\
&= 5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \\
&= 60 \end{aligned}
```
Therefore, `falling_factorial(5.0, 3)` should return `60.0`.

## Example 2
If `$x = -7$` and `$n = 4$`, then
```math
\qquad\begin{aligned} (-7)^{\underbar 4} &= (-7) \cdot (-7 - 1) \cdot (-7 - 2) \cdot (-7 - 3) \\
 &= (-7) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-9) \cdot (-10) \\ &= 5040\end{aligned}
```
Therefore, `falling_factorial(-7.0, 4)` should return `5040.0`.

## Example 3
If `$x = 17$` and `$n = 1$`, then `$17^{\underbar 1} = 17$`. Therefore, `falling_factorial(17.0, 1)` should return `17.0`. In fact, `falling_factorial(x, 1)` should always return `x`.

## Example 4
If `$x = 17$` and `$n = 0$`, then `$17^{\underbar 0}$` is an empty product (i.e., a product with zero factors). Empty products are defined to be `$1$`, so `$17^{\underbar 0} = 1$`. Therefore, `falling_factorial(17.0, 0)` should return `1.0`. In fact, `falling_factorial(x, 0)` should always return `1.0`.

#### See Also
Read more about [falling and rising factorials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falling_and_rising_factorials) on Wikipedia.
